snippet.textDisplay: Gayle King was doing her job by asking the question. Kobe tarnished his own image and it will forever follow him. People act like he was some sort of god that could do no wrong. Snoop Dogg was an idiot for chiming in on this. You never really know who these people are until you're around them in a private setting. The friend can claim what she thinks she knows about Bryant because they're friends but people hide how they are, people should know this. That's how domestic violence victims live, they pretend that everything is good in public but in private it's all shit. Who knows for sure what happened that night with that hotel worker and Bryant, only those two know the truth. If she was truly assaulted I feel for her but if she wasn't shame on her. I never paid attention to the case but who likes to have bruises around the neck or face, especially if you work in a hotel. Did she ever go back to work? Did she tell anyone at work that night what had just happened to her? I just read about the rape case and the dropping the case didn't mean she lied about anything. They made Bryant out to be the victim. It's horrible what happened to her and the fact that she reported the incident right away and only backed down when Bryant's lawyers were trying to trash her image as if ppl with mental health issues and women who sleep around like men do can't be rape victims. Now I understand why this will stick with his legacy. snippet.textDisplay: It’s coming up because when someone dies you relive their life and unfortunately that was part of his life.  As far as asking him about it when he was alive.  It was asked about.  I remember him doing a press conference with his wife present.  So it was addressed when he was alive.  I actually think it was very brave of Gayle King to touch on that subject because the truth of the matter is is that no one will ever know and it is very common for people that have experience something like that to not testify and not want to testify about it as a victim.  It’s very typical that when somebody dies every part of their life is reviewed so I think it’s a shame that Gayle King is being attacked over this I think it was actually brave of her to bring it up.  Also I think it’s great that he turned his life around after that and he did the right thing he could’ve gone either way I think he was just young and stupid and did something dumb at the end of the day he was a serial cheater and that’s another thing that is going to be a scourge on his legacy but he will be remembered for the great things that he did in sports and how he continue to better himself and do great things and inspire people. snippet.textDisplay: Like most people, I was initially disgusted with Gayle when I heard about this interview.  However, after watching a clip of the interview, and Gayle's comments about the editing, I think I'm going to give her the benefit of the doubt.  I really don't get the impression that she was trying to throw shade on Kobe. Quite the contrary, in fact. To me, it looked like she wanted to give someone (who cared about Kobe) a platform to defend his legacy and address some of the negative comments that have been circulating about him on Twitter.  People keep saying that she shouldn't have even brought it up, but sometimes it's important to set people straight and counteract negative rumours. This just feels like an unnecessary witch hunt to me.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think fans of Bryant who are upset by King’s question need to grow a thicker skin. I think it was a perfectly legitimate question for King to ask. Kobe Bryant was a public figure who left an incredible legacy which will be talked about for many years to come. The sex allegation was one negative element of his legacy and deserves to be talked about just as much as the positive stuff if we’re to have a balanced, rounded portrayal of the man; we can’t just edit out all of the negative or unflattering things about a person’s life to suit our needs because that wouldn’t be fair or honest.

And this suggestion that King has somehow betrayed Bryant and all black people by asking this question is simply bullshit. She had every right to ask it, especially considering she’s a journalist. The belief that black people should blindly refuse to question the character or actions of another black person simply because they share the same skin colour is wrong and also dangerous because it could excuse bad behaviour that otherwise deserves to be punished.

I think every right-thinking black person would agree that it would be absurd to suggest a white reporter who asked a question about a negative incident in late white celebrity’s life had betrayed all white people, and rightly so. The same applies to black people, and any other color person for that matter.

snippet.textDisplay:
First off, I get the rage...totally, but there are more appropriate ways of demonstrating and conveying it, so Snoop was off base with his reaction.

That said, journalists cannot always stand behind the "I'm just doing my job" fallback position.

I mean c'mon, have some fucking integrity. Know the difference between right and wrong. Recognize that "doing your job" sometimes goes too far and draw the fucking line somewhere.

She was wrong to go there and she knew it, but she went there anyway. This " out of context" line is pure bullshit. In ANY context, that line of questioning was irrelevant, especially when you consider that the man just lost his life.

What we have here is 2 wrongs...first her, then Snoop, but without her initiating it with her inappropriate questions, then there would have been no reaction.

It's on Gayle King. She was wrong, and she needs to learn that she is not above being called out for her insensitivity.

snippet.textDisplay:
Society needs to understand that when a celebrity like Kobe Bryant dies, the Media and other elites who have plans and intentions deliberately practice and deliberately pursue that person's legacy to deliberately taint and try to reduce the cheer and ecstatic celebration of that celebrity with what they think is balance to that person's legacy.


It's a journalistic practice that they feel all things are now open to talk about because or she is dead now. The Media had years to ask these questions to him! They had years to revisit this when:


Kobe won a number of Championships
Kobe scored number of 60 points on the floor
Kobe went against both LeBron and Curry
Kobe's final retirement
Kobe's Jersey numbers being retired
Kobe's Oscar win


No. They wait for his death. They didn't know he would die. But to take advantage of his death for the purpose of retrying this man by using Journalism is shameful.


And to everyone who thinks this was journalism. Please not that it wasn't. The moment Ms. King stated her views and opinion of Lisa's hindsight and perspective as a friend, she deliberately or accidentally showed her hand and her intentions. It was planned. It was deliberate. It was clearly her expressing that she believed him to be guilty and he got away with it and he needs to be handled by the Media and the public. That is what she did.


As for Snoop. I understand his hurt and anger, but that is NO justification for attacking her! It was not a threat on the level of actually making a hit on her life, but it was reckless abandon to his own celebrity and social media accountability and he owes her and Vanessa Bryant sincere, humbled, deep-felt apology in person. He has to go see her and talk with her and explain his mindset. And then he has to make it clear that no one is to harm her.


I think no one would. I don't think there is anyone who is a fan of Kobe or Snoop that took him literally. I believe was speaking collectively as a fan-base, a people and a social media community such as Black Twitter who would charge her and make her pay the price for maligning Kobe as she did.


That is what I believe, however, because of his persona, it was taken out of context. Susan Rice and Oprah playing a big part of that. Along with Snoop.


Let the Chips fall please where they need to for accountability sake.
